segments.text: I don't know, but what you're working on, this could be... But you kind of see it as religion of the...
I have no idea what it is.
It's all in fact or German.
But I thought you, you know, let's have you work on that.
Oh, well, fine.
Do any of your German reading friends and let's try it down.
Look at the interesting engraving, though, too.
Well, one is holding philosophy, the other is holding a Bible.
Wisdom or sapientia is radiating from a cloud.
And I don't know whether this is making fun of people who write...
Religious or anti-religious stuff or what it is, but anyway, there you are.
Given what you're writing, I thought that might be of some interest.
Thank you.
I will.
That's like many of those things you... I've got to get that magic number here.
I'll find you pack them in because you know they're going to be interesting sometimes, and
And you wonder when the sometimes... Yeah, that's great.
How long is the book?
I mean, is it... It's about 150, 200 pages.
I mean, it's a real book.
It's not a spoon for anything.
I don't know.
It might.
It could be.
It's a spoon.
It's a... It's a considerable spoon.
Well, it could be one of those philosophical...
Which is kind of fun, too.
You know, a philosophical disquisition of how stupid all these controversialists are and ridiculing religion.
Thank you for coming too.
It's me.
See if I ever come when they're having a box-building convention again.
I took that.
I took a limo in.
A limo.
I'm a man.
I'm a man.
In other words, you didn't have a private cab.
I didn't have a private cab.
We had a long chat.
As he told me, I absolutely had to meet you.
Well, what are you writing about in this new book?
It's about... Dave Kirshenbaum.
Well, back when I was about 14, I started going for anything 18th century I could find loose.
If it's cheap, I'll buy it.
I used to buy things from time to time when I was in graduate school from Carnegie Bookshop, second floor, right across from Bloomingdale.
And I would pop in there occasionally when I didn't have too much loose money to spend, but it was always an interesting place to go.
Well, one day I was in New York.
Are you getting anything here?
No, I can't.
If it's real good, I'll hold it up.
No, it's fine.
That is lovely to use it.
One day I was in New York.
I suppose this was about five or six years ago.
And late one night, I looked at the yellow pages to book dealers to see if there was anything I was missing.
Well, here was Carnegie Bookshop.
And I thought, this is extraordinary.
I thought that place closed years to come.
But here it was on, I think, something like 61st Street, 9 East 61st Street.
So just off this, that was worse.
five, six years ago.
Oh, so it's 57.
No, it's 65.
That's why five, six years ago is when I went to interview him in this very same shop.
Upstairs, little table.
Yeah, yeah, yeah, in that room there.
So I went in there, and it is the same guy.
He was 95 or 96 or 97.
He was at the age of 99.
He just died.
No, he had been in the book business since 1916 or some... It's better than that.
He's attended every major auction in New York.
From the Hole to the Manny, from 1912 to 1992.
He was a runner.
He claims to have been a runner.
At age.
Well, whatever.
Age 12 or whatever.
Even if it's apocryphal.
I put it in the book.
It was too good.
Yeah, yeah.
We don't want to check on this story.
It might not be right.
So many stories are too good.
Well, so I went in there.
And I bought all kinds of wonderful things.
He was practically giving them away.
I think he probably had a customer there at a month.
I stumbled in.
Here's a letter signed J. Mill.
I'm not sure whether it was Jon Stewart or James.
For five bucks, I wasn't on equivalent.
And you bought it?
No.
Something else from an English admiral.
Same price.
A wonderful ink.
and wash drawing of Paganini dancing on a violin.
That's a period piece.
That was maybe $10, $5 or $10.
And an album I still haven't figured out.
The paper is watermarked 1812, but it copies out all kinds of 18th century English doggoal verse and notes on who wore what at court.
It's obviously connected with the nobility.
I still haven't deciphered it, but it was a wondrous day of picking up things I least expected
and he was clearly just interested in parking them someplace where somebody wanted them.
And that's Dave.
That is Dave.
I don't know if you've read the Texas chapter of my book yet.
It's one of those things I read around him.
You say, what's he doing in Texas?
Because I was really writing about Luke Feldman.
But he knew Feldman, and Feldman wanted Dave to join ranks with him to sell to Texas.
So I really write at length.
I go off in one of these long, discursive,
things in Dave Kirshen.
It's really, if you'll enjoy this.
All right.
He talked about building collections.
Bradley Martin was his, you know, Bradley Martin's principal supplier.
Anyway, go ahead.
I'm sorry.
Well, so anyway, this has been the
The Cohen sisters at Argosy told me he had died.
One time I came and I said, your old friend there had died.
As I said, how long has this man been in the book business?
And they told me a little bit about him.
Yeah.
In fact, I've got his old bit in the book, in the footnotes.
I'll look that up.
I have my dark connection.
He's in the footnotes, and there's a long, I must say, at least 1,500, 2,000 words on him in a Texas chapter.
Mm-hmm.
Well, we don't just talk about Feldman.
We talk about what he did for NYU.
We talk about the Barrow collection.
He's got these collections.
He talks about the course he fails, whose wife told her it's either you or the books.
Let's go with the books.
You know, he's a certain age.
You know, I think that there are a lot of areas where you can help me.
And you
I love the fact that you're a president of a university here.
Well, there are several things, I think.
One of them that I would face straight out that I did mentally when somebody posed the question to me.
I am fascinated by early material just for itself.
It doesn't have to mean or be anything.
Oh, I love that quote.
Run with that.
Yeah.
Let me say it again.
No, no, that's right.
I get it the first time, but I like what you're talking about.
The man says, ooh, I'm working on that.
Stephen Jay Gould tells me he can't work from anything but the real stuff.
Oh, yeah.
He has a book.
He came out and gave a lecture, and he started talking about somebody that I thought only a book collector's would know about that.
I'm seeing his collection now in Soho.
Well, he gave me his address.
I haven't been to see him yet.
It's on Green Street.
And he said, you got an original of Archbishop Usher?
He said, oh, yeah.
Usher is the guy we should be celebrating.
that said the world was created in 4004, so this is the 6,000... That's the T.S.
's, right?
Yeah, U.S.S.H.E.R.
Not bad, right?
Yeah.

Anyway, so a long time ago, when I was first beginning to collect all this stuff one way and another, somebody said to me, well, you're interested in that just for what it tells you about today, right?
Because it gives you a perspective on today.
A long time ago, when I was teaching, when I taught at Connecticut College from 68 to 84, some time in there.
So you were already professionally formed, shall we say?

Well, in terms of, I started in high school collecting things, and then in college, whenever Northfield, Minnesota, not too much 18th century stuff was floating around loose, but occasionally I would find an English piece in the library for a duplicate sale.
I wouldn't be pleased about that now, but I was glad to buy it then.
So anytime something fell my way that I could afford, I'd add it to the old grouping.
I brought you some lists here so you could see.
And so this person said, well, you buy this just so you understand today better, you know, having a very modern utilitarian ring to all this.
And finally I learned to say, no, not at all, absolutely not.
These things are just interesting for themselves.
That's like saying a Bach fugue helps me understand the New York subway or problems of an urban environment.
No such thing.
It's just a beautiful thing in itself.
It can be appreciated without transforming it into some utilitarian link to something else.
This is not to say it doesn't make connections or have interesting aspects, but that, I think, is a very interesting thing.

thing about what you're doing that is if I collect federal furniture obviously I can sit on it I can use it at home it has a utilitarian value it's pretty it's nice it's also valuable and when I'm done with it I can sell it or do any other thing if I collect medieval bronzes I
I can look at them in a case to a limit, but I can't sit down.
They don't have that.
I can substitute this for something that otherwise would come from Woolworths or a department store or a current manufacturer at all.
With books, I think, and book people, I really believe that you walk in a room and you walk in a room
And as one of the writers on the decorative arts said in the 1870s, what you see in a room tells you what's in a mind.
Oh, I like to see.
Well, it's true.

This lady said, if you want to be impressive, make sure you have a bust of Napoleon and a few grapes and a picture of Jesus and, you know, all kinds of things to show the multiple facets of your mind.
And if you say a room represents a mind,
That's a scary thing sometimes.
Do you believe that you subscribe to him?
I do.
I do.
I think that people often surround themselves with what interests them.
And when I met a historian who had a reproduction map of, I don't know, Denmark or Germany or something on his wall, I would have dated about 1740, 1790.
A historian, an academic historian, right?
And I said, what is this map?
And he said, I don't know.
It just was decorative.
I knew something about that historian, in terms of his basic curiosity of the environment 10 feet around him.
But you go to houses, and people, more than they realize, reveal themselves by what they have sitting around.
When I was a book reviewer, we'll go beyond that.
You know, you'd like to know what people wanted to read beside their books.
Yes.
And that's really privileged information.
I decided, you know, you really do know, you really know a person by their reading habits.
When this is what they want to read or they want to collect.
The interesting thing about collecting the way I do, and I will just tell you, I really mean my motto,
It doesn't scan well dramatically.
Anything I can find cheap, 18th century, I'll buy.
Is anything.
Any country, any... Japan, China, Europe... Why do some people like vanilla and not chocolate?
Well, the 18th is easier, it's closer.
I suppose it's a fascination formed as a child with Williamsburg, Philadelphia, the revolution, colonial American history, but oddly doesn't go back to the 1600s as vigorously.
But as a fascination with the music, with the art, the architecture, virtually every aspect of what seems to be still the classic taste, and that is
Just look around this room.
Now, it borders from, I suppose, the Biedermeyer to the, you know, that's a non-Pierre light.
This is shades of a 17th century ceiling.
I suppose it averages after the 18th century, one way or another.
Let me just interrupt for a second.
Kirsten, instead of you getting a book and sending it to me, why don't you just write down who I should describe it to it?
I get books at home.
Oh, wonderful, wonderful.
Does that make more sense?
Yeah, let me just start right now.
Then I'll give you a check right in a second.
To William Horne.
William Horne.

libraries are and remain libraries are and remain a place for books a place to not only learn facts but experience cultural artifacts that is it's one thing to know that as sometimes said virgil was the great classic author of one century herodota or horus the great classic weatherman 18th century and you

You take out the editions, and you fold out the plates, and you look at the printing, and it's red and black, and it's interesting, and you see the notes, and you see the students' notes, and it's all very different from reading one of the Harvard classics, or reading a modern zippy paperback translation, when you actually touch the stuff of another century.
It's like Addison's essay on coins and metals as being basic to the library of a gentleman.
That's just how you know something about the Greeks and the Romans.
You have several drawers full of it.
So I took out this 1775 book, beautiful little gem of a thing, a tiny French book, as they did, kind of do a decimal size, and it was five dollars, leather bound, complete.
It had one on the spine, so they probably thought it was an odd volume, but it was complete in itself.
And I checked the price just to make sure it wasn't a 1910 price.
Nope.
They said, that's ours, $5.
So I showed it to him.
He kept looking at it, looking at it with great delight.
This is a horn.
Mr. Horn, yes.
And then I pulled out something that I had saw for several years and finally had found in Minnesota, James Bond's Birds of the Caribbean.
Well, if you know the secret agent, Fleming actually named him.
He was writing the stories.
He was stumped.
He had the character down.
but he needed a name.
That's great.
I don't know this.
And on his coffee table or someplace in his house, I think at Jamaica, was a book on Birds of the Caribbean by James Bond, who I think is American, not even English, ornithologist.
How many Bond collectors would pay thousands of dollars?
This is a later edition.
If they knew this, they'd have to have that book.
Oh, yeah, exactly.
So I pulled it out.
And I handed it to Mr. Horne, and he said, oh, yes, yes, yes, yes.
And I'm still not sure whether he knew the James Bond story, I mean, the movie story.
He said, oh, yes, Bond's Bird of the Caribbean.
I have this.
I'm a birder.
I'm very interested in birds.
Now, is this the first edition or the second edition?
Now, what was the point of this little show on television?
I don't know.
It's just the kind of enthusiasm people share, whether others want it or not.
But you didn't know yet whether or not he was a book man.
No, I didn't, but it turned out he was a book fanatic.
You've just kind of flown your fly on the water here, right?
Yes.
Many people come in and say, gee, the Bears really did great last night, or didn't the Expos do well?
Did they?
I don't know.
Let me show you what I found here from 1720.
I mean, that's my version of a sports story.
So I'm...
we're talking about libraries, so I wanted to show him that.
Well, not only did he know about Pond, he had used it, and he had several editions himself.
He'd been to Jamaica, he'd been to Trinidad, looking at Burns, using this book.
And so there was a good deal of back and forth, whether it was a first edition or not.
And we later went down the hall to look at his office to see whether he had it, and it was at home.
But before I left,
I said, where are there any other bookshops right around here?
Just like me, you know.
My plane doesn't go until 315.
He said, well, look at Leon's on 9th Street, Minneapolis.
So I went into Leon's, and it turns out there are two of them, Mr. and Mrs., each run a shop.
So Mr. sent me to one after I'd found some very interesting books with him.
And Mrs.,
said, I said, do you have a cookery section?
A what section?
Cookery.
And I said, as she said, you'll see it's a very small world here.
So this is how the Louise F. Murray connection comes together years later again.
No, this is not years later, last week.
It came.
So, I mean, this is just a week and a half ago.
So, do you have a cookery section?
Yes.
There was a very nice man named Zathmer, who used to come in here all the time and look at the cookery section, and his wife, she was Japanese.
I think her name was Saba or Sada or something like that.
She would come in very patiently and finally say, Louis, don't you think you've looked at those enough now?
Couldn't we go home?
And both people knew Mr. Horn.
What the point is, in the...
first place I went, because he sent me, and we talked about birth.
Here was a book, four volumes, British Ornithology, or British Zoology, 1768-1770.
It'll take me a minute to come.
Thomas Pennant, P-N-N-A-N-T, is the author.
This is the kind of symmetry there is in the world.
So I called him up, all excited.
The next day I said, thank you, thank you, thank you for sending me to this
book, to this bookshop.
I told him about this set.
And I said, there's so many engravings of birds that I thought I might copy for you.
Tell me, what's your favorite bird?
Well, the Dartford Warbler.
I never heard of the Dartford Warbler.
Probably neither did you.
And so I said, okay, I'll see if I can find a Dartford Warbler.
Well, wonder of wonders, this book was finished in 1770, the fourth volume.
The guy who wrote it
was the very man who described the category of warlords in 1773.
And there's just a kind of weird serendipity in all of this that makes life much more interesting.
It's weirdly incomprehensible to those who don't belong to this club, you know.
It happens more often than it doesn't.
It happens.
I call it, you know, and of course it sounds spiritual, but it's not.
I mean, I sometimes feel there's a hand directing me, ledging me to something.
I have it.
I used to think it was a joke.
Have you ever... Did you feel that?
I mean, sometimes it's eerie.
I mean, I'll be at home thinking I need something.
I'm writing.
And it's frustrating.
And look, and it's...
Right there, and you were looking for it for three years.
Wilmarth Lewis.
Have you ever read Wilmarth Lewis?
He's in my book.
Okay.
He's one of the few people who wrote three autobiographies.
Did you ever go to his place when he was alive?
Not while he was alive.
But it's still there.
I did.
It was a magical experience.
Farmington's.
Robbery Hill.
Here's a guy.
I love this kind of people.
who pulls out a shelf list.
He had a card catalog then.
And you pull it out and it's practically solid pink.
And he said, this is a list of my 18th century prints.
The ones with the pink overlay are the ones the British Museum doesn't have.
You know, that kind of two-fisted, oh boy.
That's Sam Berger with his Moller's collection out there in Carmel.
It blows everybody away with what he has and what they don't have.
Well, I thought it was mystic funny.
when I read Lewis's biographies, that he would go to a party, go to a house, and he knew somehow he just intuited
that there were Walpole items in the house, and it was as though they had a mystic magnetic attraction.
And I believe that.
It's as though over there behind that piano, if we just look in that bookcase, we're going to find one.
And he would get up, and the hosts would sometimes look aghast.
He would actually move something and pull out a book, aha, this belonged to Walpole himself.
I don't have a Walpole nose, but 18th century nose I do have.
I was in a bookshop in Denver.
See, how did that stuff show up in places like Denver and Minneapolis?
Well, here's the point.
I don't know.
It just travels in clumps.
I went in the shop, and I said to the man, do you have any 18th century things?
And, of course, usually they think they mean Oxford Press reprints of Dr. Johnson or something like that.
I said, no, something printed in the 18th century.
No, I haven't taken it.
And I looked around, and I said, there is something here.
And in a few minutes, I had a quarto by Robert Sanderson, a piece on mathematics, big piece, one of two volumes, very sad shape, but on algebra, 1740, as a professor at Cambridge.
I said, look what I found.
You didn't have one, but you do.
20 bucks.
Nice.
It's really great that you can get these things.
And then a week ago after, well, before we went to Minneapolis, we were in Northfield, Minnesota.
I went to Carleton down there.
Carleton didn't have any bookshops in the 60s when I was there, or at Northfield, but does now.
And I went in and I said, do you have any 18th century material?
And he said, no, we don't have anything.
I said, well, that one's there.
You got one right there?
It's 18th century or earlier.
That's before you even picked it up.
Didn't even have to open the case.
Can you judge a book by its cover?
Absolutely.
No question.
People who think you can't don't know what they're talking about.
So I said, that's 18th century, so we got it out in 1749.
Very interesting, the only 18th century English book I've ever seen found in vellum, as though it were a 17th century Italian.
Not polished vellum, it's kind of rough, almost sweaty, but it is vellum.
And so we made a deal for that one, and it's Virgil's Bucallax, and I have it now.
Do you catalogue this stuff when you take it home or is it more... It was getting out of control.
Is it a casual collection?
It's casual in terms of acquisition, but I hope rather more organized once I get home.
I do have several foci, but the interesting thing is when you bring in simply what nature offers,
Very often.
Then you begin to see more about a time period.

You may not look for books on gardens or architecture, but if you begin to have them, and you look at them, and you pour over them, then you see more about architecture and gardens in the whole period.
That's more interesting.
This is normal stuff for an Orientalist.
I'll tell you about my Japanese books in a minute, but...
in Asian studies, China and Japan, there's a deep belief that calligraphy, poetry, art, culture, architecture, history, literature, all are a kind of almost like they're a gem.
And when you talk about any one of those things, you are simply looking at one facet of the whole gem, which amounts to the total culture.
In European and American studies, we don't see things quite that way.
We think that science is divorced from art and tend to be more departmental or categorical.
But the more you know, the more unity there is, and the more interesting things you find simply because you're operating outside the normal area.
Now, I brought a couple of showing tells for you.
One of the things that intrigued me about
Your account of Louie kind of pushed me over the edge was all these cookery things that he had.
We had another alum of Illinois Wesleyan who I got to know, John Gurney, and he was a great cookbook collector.
Cagle at Louie has come out with one volume that thick that's a bibliography of the Gurney Cookbooks, and he's now about to come out with a second one.
Well, knowing Gernon, then reading about Patmery, that's kind of the current version of my cookery stuff from the 1680s.
So, cookery and then food books, or garden books, that goes along with it.
So you can just see the kind of things I've been able to pick up here.
One of the things I resist is if you already have one book, is there any reason you shouldn't acquire another?
Do you have an island garden?
No.
Do you know the book?
No.
You don't know the book?
No, no.
See, you faxed his book with it has some color.
Oh, Siri Baxter.
It's called An Island Gardener.
It's Appledore.
It's wonderful.
No, but my son went to the island a couple of years ago.
He just graduated from Andover.
I never saw a kid so taken with anything so interesting.
I never had heard of Celia Thaxter.
He was transfixed.
I was going to write a... So anyway, what am I saying here?
Oh, so these are a couple of the things that I have.
I also am very interested in musical things.
In another life, I'd have been probably, if I had a pick, Trevor Pinnock.
who is one of the great English harpsichord players, but he also has his little own group.
I have a great interest in music.
I probably don't have too many music collectors in your group, but I didn't bring this for you to... Keith, if you can look at it, I don't have a new version of this.
This is the music that I have.
This is the antiquarian music.
That's just my running list, so I know what I have and I don't have.
But I've got all of Corelli and a lot of the Valdi and Handel in 18th century printings.
So you have a computer file for this?
Is it a database?
Well, some of my record keepers are databases, but this is just a straight
text thing, and I put them in alphabetically, and it has a search function.
It's where it's perfect.
You can search that.
So that works pretty well for me.
But it keeps me from buying triples.
Doubles happen every now and then.
So you don't carry this with you.
Well, you know, sometimes if I'm going to a place where I know there's going to be a lot of cookery or a lot of this or a lot of that, I'll bring one of these lists along.
But most of the time I don't.
I'm being interested in music.
I am fascinated by the process of early music.
My watch is 15 minutes fast.
In terms of the face, I think you have the same... Oh, it's a Rolex.
Yours is a fancier one.
Mine is about 20 years old.
Mine is 28 years old.
I got this in graduate school.
Well, my parents gave me this when I was finishing up at Princeton.
I've worn it every day since, save for when it wasn't screwed in and I got salt water, and that didn't work too well.
Anyway, so I'm interested in the music.
Particularly, I've been fascinated by...
Early violins, early music.
I have a 1787 harpsichord, and what I've come to call my orchestra with no players, about 14 violins, three violas, two cellos, a bunch of other stuff.
Do you play any of these?
The harpsichord I do, and I'm beginning to attract a few players now, doing English things.
There's an amazing wealth of particularly English 18th century music,
but no one knows anything about.
So you collect these?
Yeah.
One of the fascinating aspects of collecting a bunch of things is you see lots of things that perhaps other people don't realize much about.
There's a wonderful line from Holmes.
Watson says, well, Holmes, I was with you the entire time.
How did you see all this?
And Holmes says, my dear Dr. Watson,
We saw the same things.
I simply observed them differently.
So the more things you see in a different way, the more observations you're ready to make.
We're doing a... Illinois Wesleyan is doing an exchange relation.
We're hoping to send a couple of our kids each year to Pembroke College, Oxford, as visiting students.
That's Dr. Johnson's college.
It's also...
Sir William Blackstone's college, and that's working out very interestingly.
We're going to start next year.
Can I just interrupt for a second?
Yeah.
The gentleman I had lunch with today, Abel Burland, have you ever heard of him?
Sure.
Caxton, Caxton, Caxton, and Caxton.
Abel's second folio of Shakespeare, his first folio was signed by John Dryden.
His second folio, the prokonans, is absolutely all the way through.
John's the one that Johnson used to prepare the... Right, the lives of the poets?
The man's fingerprints are... I've handled this book.

I mean, if you can't get a kick out of something like this... Well, I mean, that's the kind of talismanic thing, you know, put their hand on the object and enter another era that you just can't get with a computer screen.
Well...
There's a line for you.
Talismanic object that you just can't get with a computer screen.
But you go back to the music.
I was in London this summer.
I used to think, you know, this is, when I started out in this, people would tell me,
Now make sure, if you're going to buy books, always buy beautiful copies.
Every page there, beautiful bindings.
Spend as much as you can for the fewest number of books.
I am the absolute antithesis of that.
As I told a friend of mine, you collect bindings, I collect books.
I don't care if they have a cover.
Yeah, that's not an antiquarian attitude.
Well...
Well, it is, and this one friend I think of, he has the most elegant quartos.
He's decided to focus on quartos, and if you want to have an eat-your-heart-out day, you look at what he has.
Are you looking at the findings, or are you looking at the content?
Well, you're looking at both, and you think these are really lovely, whereas...
Mine may not have covers.
They're very wormy, and a page or two may be missing, but I haven't.
So could it be really quite irrelevant to you, or is it even if the word is too strong?
Well, again, it all depends on condition and price.
I would much rather, well, ideally you want a brilliant book for minimal price, but the best of all possible worlds is five books you really want at the price of one in pristine condition.
where you don't want them on.
But to go back to the music thing, when I was in London, a book dealer or a music dealer had made me an offer, which we were able to come to terms.
She had said, I have a group of miscellaneous parts from the 18th century.
Miscellaneous?
Parts.
Parts.
